def: {bc} a particular kind or group of things or people
{bc} a particular kind of person
{bc} printed letters

dt: {bc}a particular kind or group of things or people

dt.t: What {it}type{/it} [={it}sort{/it}] of food do you like?
We were not prepared to face this {it}type{/it} of crisis.
We studied various {it}types{/it} of trees.
a seedless {it}type{/it} of orange
Allergies of this {it}type{/it} [={it}kind{/it}] are common.
He only likes two {it}types{/it} of music.
She likes all {it}types{/it} of books.
She's a real outdoors {it}type{/it}. [=she loves hiking, camping, etc., in the outdoors]
The dinner guests were mostly urban {it}types{/it}. [=people who lived in the city]
He's {phrase}not her type{/phrase}. [=he is not the kind of man she is attracted to]
Her mother is {phrase}not the type{/phrase} to complain. [=she does not often complain]
italic {it}type{/it}

dt: {bc}small metal blocks that are used for printing letters and numbers on paper

dt.t: lead {it}type{/it}

shortdef: a particular kind or group of things or people
a particular kind of person
printed letters

def: {bc} to write with a computer keyboard or typewriter
{it}technical{/it} {bc} to find out what group something is in

dt: {bc}to write with a computer keyboard or typewriter

dt.t: How fast can you {it}type{/it}?
I never learned how to {it}type{/it}.
{it}Type{/it} your name here.
She asked her secretary to {it}type{/it} a memo.
Can you {it}type{/it} this {it}up{/it} for me?

dt: {bc}to find out what group something is in

dt.t: The lab will {it}type{/it} this blood sample. [=the lab will determine what type of blood the sample is]

shortdef: to write with a computer keyboard or typewriter —sometimes + up
to find out what group something is in

def: {it}chiefly US{/it} {bc} one of the eight different blood categories into which humans are separated

dt: {bc}one of the eight different blood categories into which humans are separated
These categories of blood are labeled A, B, AB, or O and each of these is either Rh-positive or Rh-negative.

dt.t: Her {it}blood type{/it} is B negative.

shortdef: one of the eight different blood categories into which humans are separated —called also blood group

def: {bc} to type without looking at the keyboard

dt: {bc}to type without looking at the keyboard

dt.t: The class taught him how to {it}touch-type{/it}.

shortdef: to type without looking at the keyboard

def: {bc} one more of the same kind {bc} another one
{bc} one that is different {bc} someone or something else

dt: {bc}one more of the same kind {bc}another one

dt.t: I've had one drink, but I think I'll have {it}another{/it}.
One copy of the letter was sent out, and {it}another{/it} was placed in the files.
One thief carried a gun, {it}another{/it} (carried) a knife.
This cup is chipped. Could you please bring me {it}another{/it}?
We had dinner at {it}another{/it} of the city's many Italian restaurants.

dt: {bc}one that is different {bc}someone or something else

dt.t: She's not comfortable living in {it}another's{/it} house. [=in another person's house]
Complaining about problems is one thing, but finding solutions to them is {it}another{/it}. [=it is more difficult to find solutions to problems than to complain about them]
The family seems to move from one city to {it}another{/it}.

dt: used in phrases with {it}one{/it} or (less commonly) {it}some{/it} to refer to something that is not specified

dt.t: We all do foolish things {phrase}at one time or another{/phrase}. [={it}sometimes{/it}, {it}on occasion{/it}]
They had to change their plans {phrase}for one/some reason or another{/phrase}. [=for some reason]
He vowed that he would succeed (in) {phrase}one way or another{/phrase}. [=vowed that he would find a way to succeed]
a lock {phrase}of one kind/sort/type or another{/phrase} [=some kind/sort/type of lock]
What with {phrase}one thing and another{/phrase}, we still haven't finished. [=we still haven't finished because of various things that have happened]
The buses kept arriving, {it}one after another{/it}.
{it}One{/it} person {it}after another{/it} walked out of the concert.
{it}One after another{/it} of her friends got married and moved away.

shortdef: one more of the same kind : another one
one that is different : someone or something else
—used in phrases with one or (less commonly) some to refer to something that is not specified
blood type

def: {bc} to go back or return to (an earlier state, condition, situation, etc.)
{it}law{/it}, {it}of property{/it} {bc} to be given to (a former owner or a former owner's heir)

dt: {bc}to go back or return to (an earlier state, condition, situation, etc.)

dt.t: She has {it}reverted{/it} (back) {it}to{/it} her old habits.
My blood pressure has {phrase}reverted to normal{/phrase}. [=has returned to normal; has become normal again]
After playing badly in the last two games, he seems to have {phrase}reverted to form{/phrase}. [=he is now playing as well as he usually does]
({it}chiefly Brit{/it}) After this one atypical comedy, will he {phrase}revert to type{/phrase} [=will he do what he usually does] in his next film?

dt: {bc}to be given to (a former owner or a former owner's heir)

dt.t: The estate {it}reverted to{/it} a distant cousin.

def: {bc} not speaking or making noise
{bc} tending not to talk much
{bc} not having or making any sound or noise

dt.t: She was {it}silent{/it} for a few minutes as she thought about how to answer him.
Please be {it}silent{/it}.
The crowd {phrase}fell silent{/phrase} as the horrible news was read aloud.
My father was a very {it}silent{/it} man.
He was {phrase}the strong, silent type{/phrase}.

dt: {bc}not having or making any sound or noise

dt.t: He said he would call me, but the phone was {it}silent{/it} all day.
The radio went {it}silent{/it}. [={it}dead{/it}]
A long, {it}silent{/it} pause followed her reply.
She offered a {it}silent{/it} prayer of thanks for her family's safety.
They nodded their heads in {it}silent{/it} agreement.
He turned his back on the president in {it}silent{/it} protest.

dt: {bc}giving no information about something or refusing to discuss something

dt.t: History books are {it}silent{/it} about this shameful incident in our nation's past.
The president remained {it}silent{/it} on the issue of funding.
You have the {phrase}right to remain silent{/phrase}. [=the legal right not to say anything when you are arrested]

dt: {bc}written in the spelling of a word but not pronounced

dt.t: There is a {it}silent{/it} {ldquo}e{rdquo} in {ldquo}cane.{rdquo}
The {ldquo}b{rdquo} in {ldquo}debt{rdquo} is {it}silent{/it}.
{it}silent{/it} movies/films

dt: {bc}of or relating to movies that have no spoken dialogue

dt.t: filmmakers of the {it}silent{/it} era

utxt.t: The tiger moved {it}silently{/it} through the jungle.

shortdef: not speaking or making noise : quiet
tending not to talk much
not having or making any sound or noise
